From this dataset, the team recovered hundreds of previously unknown genomes belonging to Asgard archaea, a group widely regarded as the closest living relatives of the organism that gave rise to all complex life. The effort nearly doubled the known genomic diversity of the entire Asgard group and revealed previously unrecognized protein families, doubling the number of recognized enzymatic classes within these microbes.

The central finding challenges a longstanding assumption. Most known Asgard archaea inhabit oxygen-free deep-sea environments, which made it difficult to explain how they could have partnered with oxygen-dependent alphaproteobacteria — the symbiotic merger that scientists believe produced the first eukaryotic cell and its energy-producing mitochondria. Baker's team discovered that a subgroup called Heimdallarchaeia, the Asgards most closely related to eukaryotes, actually thrives in oxygen-rich shallow coastal sediments and open water columns. These organisms possess multiple metabolic pathways for oxygen use. Using the AI protein-structure prediction tool AlphaFold2, the researchers demonstrated that several Heimdallarchaeia proteins closely resemble those eukaryotic cells use today for oxygen-based energy metabolism.

The timeline reinforces the case. Following the Great Oxidation Event more than 1.7 billion years ago, when atmospheric oxygen levels surged, the earliest known eukaryotic microfossils appear in the geological record within a few hundred thousand years. "Oxygen appeared in the environment, and Asgards adapted to that," Baker said. "They found an energetic advantage to using oxygen, and then they evolved into eukaryotes."

The research, which grew from co-author Kathryn Appler's doctoral work beginning in 2019 at the UT Marine Science Institute, involved collaborators at Monash University in Australia, Wageningen University in the Netherlands, and several other institutions. Funding came in part from the Gordon and Betty Moore and Simons Foundations. By resolving the oxygen paradox at the heart of eukaryotic origins, the study offers the strongest evidence yet that breathable air was not merely a backdrop to the emergence of complex life — it was a catalyst.

articles.headline: Giant Virus Found in Japan Bolsters Theory That Viruses Sparked Complex Life
articles.subheadline: Ushikuvirus, isolated from a Japanese lake, exhibits unusual nuclear-disrupting behavior that bridges gaps in viral evolution
articles.body:
A newly identified giant virus isolated from a lake in Japan is providing fresh evidence for one of biology's most provocative hypotheses: that viruses may have given rise to the nucleus at the heart of all complex cells, effectively catalyzing the emergence of eukaryotic life on Earth.

The virus, named ushikuvirus after Lake Ushiku in Ibaraki Prefecture, was described in a study published in the Journal of Virology by a team led by Professor Masaharu Takemura of Tokyo University of Science alongside collaborators at Japan's National Institute of Natural Sciences. Ushikuvirus infects vermamoeba, a single-celled amoeba, and belongs to the broader group of giant DNA viruses — entities so large and genetically complex that they blur the traditional boundary between viruses and living cells. What makes this particular specimen significant is the way it replicates: unlike related viruses in the Mamonoviridae family, which commandeer the host cell's intact nucleus as a factory for producing new viral particles, ushikuvirus actively breaks down the nuclear membrane during replication.

That distinction matters because it positions ushikuvirus as a potential evolutionary link between two previously separate categories of giant viruses — those that replicate inside an intact nucleus, like medusavirus, and those that dismantle the nuclear membrane entirely, like pandoravirus. Takemura, who along with Macquarie University's Philip Bell independently proposed the viral eukaryogenesis hypothesis in 2001, argues that such intermediate behaviors strengthen the case that a large DNA virus once established a stable symbiotic relationship inside an ancient archaeal cell, eventually transforming into the membrane-bound nucleus found in all eukaryotes today. That hypothesis gained significant traction after the first giant DNA viruses were discovered in 2003, revealing that some viral infections produce membrane-enclosed "virus factories" inside host cells that bear a striking resemblance to primitive nuclei.

Beyond its evolutionary implications, ushikuvirus presents a suite of distinctive physical features. Its capsid surface is studded with spiked structures capped by unique formations, some trailing filament-like extensions never observed in related medusaviruses. Infected vermamoeba cells swell to unusual sizes, a cytopathic effect distinct from those caused by other known giant viruses. The research team — which included master's students Jiwan Bae and Narumi Hantori, along with Dr. Raymond Burton-Smith and Professor Kazuyoshi Murata — notes that these differences likely reflect long-term adaptation to different amoeba hosts.

The discovery also carries potential medical relevance. Certain amoeba species closely related to those infected by giant viruses can cause life-threatening conditions, including amoebic encephalitis. Understanding how giant viruses infiltrate and destroy amoebae could eventually inform new strategies for treating such infections. "Giant viruses can be said to be a treasure trove whose world has yet to be fully understood," Takemura said. "One of the future possibilities of this research is to provide humanity with a new view that connects the world of living organisms with the world of viruses."

articles.headline: New Method Measures Relativistic Temperature Using Only Stochastic Noise
articles.subheadline: Physicist demonstrates that electromagnetic fluctuations alone can reveal the full thermal state of a fast-moving plasma
articles.body:
A new theoretical framework shows that the temperature and velocity of a relativistic medium can be extracted purely from the random electromagnetic noise it naturally emits — eliminating the need for external probes, spectral line analysis, or absolute intensity calibration.

Published on the arXiv preprint server on February 18, physicist Ira Wolfson presents a method for reconstructing the inverse-temperature four-vector, the fundamental quantity describing thermal equilibrium in special relativity. Unlike classical thermodynamics, where temperature is a simple scalar, relativistic systems require a four-component object — denoted β^μ — that encodes both the rest-frame temperature and the medium's bulk drift velocity relative to an observer. Wolfson's key insight is that when a hot, moving plasma emits thermal radiation, a Lorentz boost transforms what would be isotropic noise in the plasma's rest frame into a distinctive pattern of correlated electric and magnetic field fluctuations. These correlations contain enough information to determine the drift velocity without any external reference.

The approach leverages the covariant fluctuation-dissipation theorem, a cornerstone result connecting thermal noise to the dissipative properties of a system. By measuring angle-resolved noise spectra from the electromagnetic emissions, the full four-vector β^μ can be assembled using only passive detection of stochastic fields. Critically, the method relies on a gain-independent observable — a ratio of fluctuation quantities that cancels out detector calibration factors — making it robust against the systematic uncertainties that typically plague precision plasma diagnostics.

Monte Carlo simulations reported in the four-page paper demonstrate that the technique achieves percent-level accuracy at realistic signal-to-noise ratios. Feasibility estimates suggest that for laboratory plasmas, integration times on the order of sub-microsecond durations would be sufficient, placing the method well within reach of existing experimental capabilities. This speed could prove valuable in transient plasma experiments, including those in fusion energy research and high-energy-density physics, where conditions change rapidly.

Wolfson describes this as the first method capable of reconstructing the covariant thermal state of a relativistic medium from passive stochastic fields alone. If validated experimentally, the technique would establish vacuum electromagnetic fluctuations as a direct, operational probe of relativistic equilibrium — a conceptual advance that bridges plasma physics, statistical mechanics, and general relativity. The work has been cross-listed across all three of those arXiv categories, signaling its interdisciplinary significance.

articles.headline: New AI Framework Embeds Maxwell's Equations Into Diffusion Models for Photonic Design
articles.subheadline: MxDiffusion uses a two-stage physics-guided approach that outperforms purely data-driven methods for inverse metasurface engineering
articles.body:
A team of researchers has developed a novel generative AI framework that bakes the fundamental laws of electromagnetism directly into a diffusion model, enabling more accurate and physically consistent design of photonic metasurfaces — nanoscale structures that manipulate light in ways natural materials cannot.

The system, called MxDiffusion, was introduced in a preprint by Sujoy Mondal, Taehyuk Park, Sudipta Biswas, Alan X. Wang, and Wenshan Cai. Unlike conventional machine learning approaches to inverse photonic design, which rely entirely on training data to learn the relationship between a desired optical response and the structure that produces it, MxDiffusion incorporates Maxwell's equations — the foundational laws governing electromagnetic wave behavior — as an explicit constraint during model training. The result is a hybrid physics-and-data-driven system that generates photonic structures from target optical properties with significantly higher fidelity, particularly in challenging design scenarios.

The framework operates through a two-stage strategy. In the first stage, a diffusion model is trained using a loss function derived directly from Maxwell's equations, embedding physical principles into the generation process and producing a physically consistent intermediate representation. The second stage then translates that intermediate output into a final structural geometry. This division of labor allows the model to maintain physical plausibility while still leveraging the flexibility and generative power of modern diffusion architectures.

The researchers validated MxDiffusion on two representative test cases: gold nanostructures patterned on a silica substrate and a highly tunable bandpass filter based on phase-change material. In both scenarios, the physics-guided framework consistently outperformed a conventional data-driven diffusion model benchmark. The advantages were most pronounced for out-of-training-distribution design targets — cases where the desired optical response falls outside the range of examples the model was trained on — and for highly constrained resonance conditions, where small structural errors can produce large deviations in optical behavior.

The work addresses a persistent bottleneck in nanophotonics. Designing metasurfaces traditionally requires computationally expensive electromagnetic simulations, and purely data-driven inverse design methods often struggle with generalization and physical accuracy. By grounding the generative process in Maxwell's equations, MxDiffusion offers what the authors describe as a general physics-guided inverse design paradigm — one that could extend beyond photonics to other domains where governing physical laws can be mathematically encoded into machine learning pipelines. The preprint was posted to arXiv on February 18, 2026.

articles.headline: Paramount Skydance Clears Key Antitrust Hurdle in $77.9B Warner Bid
articles.subheadline: Hart-Scott-Rodino waiting period expires, but Justice Department could still challenge the mega-merger
articles.body:
Paramount Skydance announced Friday that it faces no remaining statutory barrier in the United States to completing its proposed $77.9 billion acquisition of Warner Bros. Discovery, after a critical antitrust review period expired without federal action to block the deal.

The company said it has fully complied with the U.S. Justice Department's second-request review process under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act, a procedural step that allows regulators to scrutinize large mergers before they close. A mandatory 10-day waiting period following that compliance lapsed on Thursday, removing one of the most significant regulatory checkpoints standing between the two entertainment giants and a transformative combination.

However, the expiration of the waiting period does not constitute regulatory approval. The Justice Department retains the authority to file suit to block the merger at any point, and has done so in past cases even after HSR waiting periods have passed. The distinction is an important one for investors and industry observers watching what would be one of the largest media deals in history — a transaction that would unite Paramount's film studio, CBS network, and streaming platform with Warner Bros. Discovery's sprawling portfolio of assets including HBO, CNN, and the Warner Bros. film and television operations.

The deal, which would reshape the competitive landscape of an entertainment industry already under intense pressure from streaming economics and cord-cutting, has drawn scrutiny from analysts questioning whether regulators in the current administration would permit such extensive consolidation. A combined entity would control an enormous share of scripted television production, film distribution, and streaming content, potentially raising concerns about market concentration and bargaining power over distributors.

Paramount Skydance — itself the product of Skydance Media's recent takeover of the legacy Paramount operation — framed the milestone as significant forward progress, stating it sees "no statutory impediment" to closing. Yet the path to completion likely involves additional regulatory reviews in international jurisdictions, and the Justice Department's silence should not be read as tacit endorsement. For now, the mega-merger remains alive, but far from assured.

articles.headline: New Asymptotic Solution Captures Heat Effects of EM Beams on Skin
articles.subheadline: Researchers derive closed-form expressions that account for both incident angle and lateral heat conduction in electromagnetic skin heating
articles.body:
A team of researchers has developed a more complete mathematical framework for predicting how electromagnetic beams heat biological skin tissue, closing a gap in previous models that failed to capture the significant effects of lateral heat conduction at realistic length scales.

The study, posted to the arXiv preprint server on February 18 by Ulises Jaime-Yepez, Hongyun Wang, Shannon E. Foley, and Hong Zhou, extends earlier work that derived only the leading-term asymptotic solution for temperature distribution during electromagnetic skin heating at arbitrary incident angles. The new analysis provides closed-form analytical expressions for both the first-order and second-order terms in an asymptotic expansion, enabling substantially more accurate temperature predictions — particularly in scenarios where the ratio of beam penetration depth to lateral beam size is moderate rather than vanishingly small.

The asymptotic approach exploits the fact that electromagnetic beams penetrate skin to a depth much smaller than their cross-sectional width, allowing the temperature field to be expanded in powers of this small depth-to-lateral scale ratio. A key finding is that while the incident angle of the beam affects all terms in the expansion, lateral heat conduction — the sideways spreading of thermal energy through tissue — appears only in terms of positive even powers. This means the leading-term solution, which was the state of the art from prior work, entirely misses the contribution of lateral conduction. At a depth-to-lateral ratio of 0.1, a value the authors characterize as moderate and physically relevant, the lateral conduction effect proves "quite significant" and cannot be neglected in any meaningful approximation.

The work spans classical physics and biological physics, reflecting its dual relevance to electromagnetic theory and biomedical applications. Electromagnetic skin heating arises in contexts ranging from medical therapies and dermatological treatments to safety assessments of radiation exposure. Accurate modeling of temperature distributions in tissue is critical for predicting thermal damage thresholds, optimizing therapeutic protocols, and understanding how beam geometry and orientation influence heating patterns beneath the skin surface.

The paper, which the authors describe as a preprint to be submitted for publication, represents a meaningful advance in the analytical toolkit available for these problems. By providing exact closed-form expressions rather than purely numerical solutions, the framework offers both computational efficiency and physical transparency — allowing researchers and engineers to directly see how each parameter governs the thermal response of irradiated tissue.

articles.headline: Tesla Fails to Overturn $243 Million Autopilot Crash Verdict
articles.subheadline: Federal judge rejects automaker's motion, saying arguments were already 'considered and rejected' during trial
articles.body:
A federal judge has denied Tesla's attempt to reverse a $243 million jury verdict that found the automaker partially liable for a fatal 2019 crash in Florida involving its Autopilot driver assistance system, dealing a significant blow to the company's legal defense of the technology.

Hon. Judge Beth Bloom ruled on February 20 that Tesla's arguments for overturning the verdict were essentially recycled from earlier stages of the litigation. "The grounds for relief that Tesla relies upon are virtually the same as those Tesla put forth previously during the course of trial and in their briefings on summary judgment — arguments that were already considered and rejected," the judge wrote, adding that Tesla failed to present any new legal arguments or controlling law that would justify altering the jury's decision.

The case stems from a 2019 crash in Florida that killed Naibel Benavides and critically injured Dillon Angulo. Last August, a jury awarded $243 million in damages, assigning two-thirds of the blame to the driver and one-third to Tesla. In a notable detail, the jury levied punitive damages exclusively against Tesla — a signal that jurors found the company's conduct warranted punishment beyond simple compensation. Tesla's legal team had argued that responsibility for the crash rested squarely with the driver.

The ruling carries broad implications for Tesla as it faces mounting legal scrutiny over its driver assistance technology. Autopilot, which handles certain steering, acceleration, and braking functions, has been at the center of numerous lawsuits and federal investigations. Critics have long argued that Tesla's marketing and naming of the system encourages drivers to over-rely on technology that still requires active human supervision. The company maintains that Autopilot is designed to assist — not replace — an attentive driver.

The decision arrives at a sensitive moment for Tesla, which continues to push aggressively into autonomous driving with its Full Self-Driving software. With the $243 million verdict now upheld, the case could embolden plaintiffs in other pending Autopilot-related lawsuits and increase pressure on regulators to impose stricter oversight on advanced driver assistance systems across the industry.

articles.headline: Blue Owl Offloads $1.4B Loan Portfolio to Pensions, Own Insurer
articles.subheadline: Alternative asset manager tapped North America's largest pension funds and its affiliated insurance unit to meet fund redemption deadline
articles.body:
Blue Owl Capital sold a $1.4 billion portfolio of private loans to four buyers — three of North America's largest pension funds and its own insurance asset management arm — as the firm raced to return capital to investors in one of its private credit funds ahead of a looming redemption deadline.

The transaction underscores the growing entanglement between alternative asset managers, institutional pension capital, and affiliated insurance platforms in the rapidly expanding private credit market. Blue Owl, which has built itself into one of the sector's most prominent players, turned to a mix of external and internal buyers to liquidate the loan book, a maneuver that highlights both the depth of institutional demand for private debt and the potential conflicts that arise when firms sell assets to entities they control.

The sale to Blue Owl's own insurance asset manager is likely to draw particular scrutiny. Asset managers that also operate or advise insurance affiliates have faced mounting regulatory attention over concerns that captive insurers can serve as convenient warehouses for assets that might otherwise be difficult to move. Regulators and ratings agencies have increasingly questioned whether such arrangements adequately protect policyholders and whether pricing reflects true arm's-length terms.

For the pension funds involved, the deal represents an opportunity to acquire seasoned private credit assets at a time when many institutional allocators are actively increasing their exposure to the asset class. Pension systems across North America have been shifting portfolios toward private markets in search of higher yields and diversification away from publicly traded fixed income, a trend that has accelerated as private credit has expanded to fill lending gaps left by traditional banks.

Blue Owl Capital, publicly traded on the New York Stock Exchange, has amassed significant scale in direct lending and other alternative credit strategies. The firm's ability to orchestrate a $1.4 billion secondary sale to meet investor redemptions suggests both robust demand for its loan assets and the operational complexity of managing liquidity in funds that invest in inherently illiquid instruments. The transaction serves as a case study in how private credit managers navigate the tension between long-duration assets and investors' periodic need for cash.

articles.headline: Teneo Warns SCOTUS Tariff Ruling Adds New Layer of Market Uncertainty
articles.subheadline: Political risk adviser says Supreme Court decision compounds existing corporate damage from trade policy
articles.body:
A recent Supreme Court ruling on tariffs has injected fresh uncertainty into markets already grappling with the financial toll of trade restrictions on corporate America, according to a senior political risk adviser at Teneo.

Kevin Kajiwara, co-president of political risk advisory at the consulting firm, said in a Bloomberg Television appearance on Thursday that while tariffs have already left visible marks on corporate income statements and balance sheets, the high court's decision introduces an additional dimension of unpredictability for businesses and investors. Speaking on Bloomberg's "The Close" with Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld, Kajiwara outlined how the legal landscape surrounding trade policy is now compounding the economic pressures companies have been absorbing for months.

The comments underscore a growing concern among risk consultants and market strategists that U.S. trade policy has become a multi-front challenge for corporations. Beyond the direct cost increases from tariffs — which have forced companies to raise prices, absorb margin compression, or restructure supply chains — firms must now contend with evolving judicial interpretations of executive trade authority. The Supreme Court's involvement signals that the constitutional boundaries of tariff powers remain a live and contested legal question, one with potentially far-reaching consequences for how aggressively the executive branch can deploy trade barriers.

Kajiwara also flagged geopolitical tensions surrounding Iran as a concurrent risk factor for markets. The convergence of trade uncertainty with Middle Eastern security concerns creates a complex backdrop for corporate planning and investor positioning heading into the spring. Teneo, which advises major multinational companies on navigating political and regulatory risks, has seen demand for its services rise as firms struggle to scenario-plan amid overlapping policy and geopolitical disruptions.

For market participants, the message is sobering: tariff risk is no longer confined to spreadsheet calculations of duty rates and sourcing costs. It now encompasses constitutional law, judicial unpredictability, and the potential for abrupt shifts in the legal framework governing international trade — all layered atop a geopolitical environment that shows few signs of stabilizing.

articles.headline: Blue Owl Capital Offloads $1.4B Loan Portfolio to Pensions, Own Insurance Arm
articles.subheadline: Private credit giant tapped three major North American pension funds and its in-house insurer to meet investor redemption deadline
articles.body:
Blue Owl Capital arranged the sale of a $1.4 billion portfolio of loans from one of its private credit funds to four buyers, including three of North America's largest pension funds and the firm's own insurance asset management division, according to Bloomberg.

The deal was driven by an approaching deadline that required Blue Owl to return capital to investors in the fund. By assembling a group of institutional buyers willing to absorb the sizable loan book, the alternative asset manager was able to generate the liquidity needed to meet its payout obligations. The involvement of Blue Owl's own insurance arm in the transaction, however, is likely to draw scrutiny from market observers who monitor potential conflicts of interest when firms act on both sides of a deal.

The transaction underscores a growing dynamic in private credit markets, where managers increasingly rely on large institutional buyers — particularly pension funds and insurance companies hungry for yield — to provide secondary liquidity for portfolios that were originally designed to be held to maturity. As private credit has ballooned into a multi-trillion-dollar asset class, the infrastructure for trading and recycling these illiquid positions has become a critical piece of the market's plumbing.

Blue Owl, which manages more than $200 billion in assets across private credit, GP stakes, and real estate strategies, has built one of the largest direct lending platforms in the industry. The New York-based firm has expanded aggressively into insurance asset management, a channel that has become a major source of permanent capital for alternative managers. That Blue Owl turned partly to its own insurance unit to absorb loans from a separate fund highlights how vertically integrated many of these platforms have become.

For the pension funds involved, the acquisition represents an opportunity to gain exposure to seasoned private credit assets at potentially attractive terms, bypassing the typical blind-pool commitment structure. The identities of the three pension buyers were not disclosed. The deal also reflects the broader trend of Canadian and American public pension systems allocating increasing shares of their portfolios to private debt as they seek returns above what public fixed-income markets currently offer.

articles.headline: Weinstein's Saba, Cox Launch Tender Offers for Blue Owl BDC Shares
articles.subheadline: Activist investor moves on Blue Owl's business development companies amid growing private credit market concerns
articles.body:
Activist investor Boaz Weinstein's Saba Capital Management, along with Cox, has launched tender offers for shares in Blue Owl Capital's business development companies, seizing on a turbulent stretch for the lender and mounting anxiety over risks accumulating in the $1.8 trillion private credit market.

The move represents an escalation by Weinstein, who has built a reputation as one of Wall Street's most aggressive activist investors, particularly in the closed-end fund space. Blue Owl Capital, a major player in alternative asset management, operates several BDCs that provide financing to middle-market companies — vehicles that have surged in popularity as private credit has ballooned into one of the fastest-growing corners of finance.

The tender offers come after what Bloomberg described as a challenging week for Blue Owl, though the specific difficulties were not detailed. The broader context, however, is unmistakable: investors and regulators alike have grown increasingly wary of the rapid expansion of private credit, which has swelled to roughly $1.8 trillion in assets. Critics warn that the sector's explosive growth, fueled by years of institutional capital flooding into alternatives, may be masking credit quality issues that could surface as economic conditions shift.

BDCs, which are publicly traded vehicles that lend to private companies, often trade at discounts to their net asset value — a gap that activist investors like Weinstein have historically targeted. By launching tender offers, Saba and Cox are effectively betting they can acquire shares below intrinsic value, pressuring Blue Owl's management in the process. Weinstein's Saba Capital has been involved in numerous campaigns against closed-end funds and similar structures, frequently pushing for measures to narrow trading discounts.

The campaign adds another front to the growing tension between alternative asset managers and activist investors who argue that certain fund structures inadequately serve shareholders. For Blue Owl, which has built a significant franchise in private credit and GP stakes investing, the tender offers could force a public defense of its BDC valuations and governance at a moment when the broader market is already scrutinizing the sector's fundamentals.

articles.headline: NASA Sets March 6 Launch for Artemis II, Humanity's Farthest Space Voyage
articles.subheadline: Four astronauts will loop around the far side of the Moon in a 10-day mission, the first crewed lunar flight in over 50 years
articles.body:
NASA has confirmed a target launch date of March 6 for Artemis II, the mission that will send four astronauts around the Moon and back — marking humanity's deepest venture into space and the first crewed lunar voyage since the Apollo era ended in 1972.

The agency locked in the date after completing a successful "wet dress rehearsal" at Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Thursday, a critical test in which the 98-meter-tall Space Launch System (SLS) rocket was fully loaded with propellant and taken through its countdown sequence. The milestone came on the team's second attempt; an earlier rehearsal in early February was cut short by a hydrogen fuel leak at the launch pad. NASA's Lori Glaze told a Friday press conference that seal and filter issues had been resolved, and that the rocket was fueled within the planned timeline. The four-person crew — Americans Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch, joined by Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen — entered quarantine on Friday.

The 10-day mission profile calls for the crew to spend their first day orbiting Earth inside the Orion capsule, a cabin roughly the size of a minibus mounted atop the SLS. If systems check out, they will fire toward the Moon on a four-day transit, swinging around its far side at an altitude of 6,500 to 9,500 kilometers above the lunar surface. The astronauts will have several hours to study and photograph the Moon before beginning a four-day return trip, culminating in a splashdown in the Pacific Ocean. The SLS has flown only once before, carrying an uncrewed Orion capsule on the Artemis I test flight in November 2022.

A successful Artemis II would set the stage for Artemis III, the mission intended to put boots on the lunar surface for the first time in more than half a century. NASA has targeted 2028 for that landing, though the timeline remains ambitious. SpaceX holds the contract to build the Artemis III lunar lander using a variant of its Starship vehicle, but persistent delays have prompted NASA to request an accelerated development plan. The agency has also asked Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos's space company, to propose a faster path to the Moon as a potential alternative.

The urgency is partly geopolitical. China has announced plans for a crewed lunar landing by 2030 and has demonstrated steady progress toward that goal. Both the United States and China are eyeing the Moon's south pole as the prime location for future bases, creating a new era of space competition that lends strategic weight to every launch window NASA can meet.

articles.headline: Russian Fuel Tanker Headed for Cuba Tests Trump Sanctions Regime
articles.subheadline: The shipment challenges U.S. blockade enforcement as Cuba's energy crisis deepens and geopolitical tensions mount
articles.body:
A tanker believed to be loaded with Russian fuel is currently en route to Cuba, setting up a direct confrontation with the Trump administration's sanctions apparatus as the Caribbean island nation grapples with a worsening energy emergency.

The vessel's voyage, first reported by Bloomberg on February 20, represents one of the most visible tests yet of Washington's willingness and ability to enforce its economic restrictions on both Cuba and Russia simultaneously. The Trump administration has pursued an aggressive sanctions posture toward Havana, building on measures tightened during the president's first term and further expanded since his return to office. Russia, meanwhile, remains subject to sweeping U.S. financial and trade penalties stemming from its invasion of Ukraine.

Cuba has been mired in a severe energy crisis that has left millions of residents enduring rolling blackouts, fuel shortages, and collapsing infrastructure. The island's antiquated power grid, heavily dependent on imported petroleum, has struggled to meet even basic demand. Russia has historically been a key energy supplier to Cuba, stepping into a role once filled by Venezuela, whose own economic troubles have curtailed its ability to deliver subsidized oil to allied nations.

The shipment poses a delicate enforcement question for Washington. Intercepting or deterring the tanker would signal robust sanctions enforcement but could escalate tensions with Moscow at a moment when U.S.-Russia relations are already under intense scrutiny. Allowing the delivery to proceed, however, risks undermining the credibility of the broader sanctions framework and inviting further attempts to circumvent American restrictions. The scenario also highlights the persistent challenge of policing global maritime trade routes, where sanctions evasion tactics — including ship-to-ship transfers, flag changes, and opaque ownership structures — have become increasingly sophisticated.

The situation underscores the broader geopolitical chess match playing out in the Western Hemisphere, where Russia has maintained strategic relationships with Cuba, Venezuela, and Nicaragua even as the United States has sought to isolate those governments economically and diplomatically. How the Trump administration responds to this particular shipment could set a precedent for future enforcement actions and signal its priorities in balancing Cuba policy against its wider approach to Russia.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Tariff Ruling Sparks Rally in Emerging-Market Assets
articles.subheadline: BlackRock's flagship emerging-market ETF surges to all-time high as currencies recover weekly losses following landmark decision
articles.body:
Emerging-market stocks, currencies, and bonds rallied sharply after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down President Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs, removing one of the most significant headwinds that had weighed on developing economies for months.

The landmark ruling sent a wave of relief through global markets, with emerging-market currencies erasing their weekly losses in a single session. BlackRock's flagship emerging-market exchange-traded fund surged to a record high as investors rapidly repriced the outlook for trade-dependent economies that had been most vulnerable to the tariff regime. The decision effectively invalidated the broad-based import duties that Trump had imposed, which had disrupted supply chains and dampened growth prospects across Asia, Latin America, and other developing regions.

The court's intervention marks a pivotal turning point for emerging markets, which had been caught in the crossfire of escalating trade tensions. Nations that rely heavily on exports to the United States — including major manufacturing hubs in Southeast Asia and commodity producers in Latin America — stand to benefit most directly from the removal of tariff barriers. The ruling also alleviates pressure on central banks in developing countries that had been forced to defend their currencies against dollar strength driven in part by trade uncertainty.

The rally in the BlackRock ETF to all-time highs signals that institutional investors are moving quickly to rebuild positions in emerging-market assets. Portfolio flows into developing economies had slowed significantly during the tariff regime, as fund managers weighed the risks of holding assets in countries facing potential export disruptions. With that overhang now lifted by the Supreme Court, strategists expect a period of sustained inflows as valuations in many emerging markets remain attractive relative to developed-market peers.

While the immediate market reaction has been overwhelmingly positive, analysts caution that the broader policy landscape remains uncertain. The Trump administration could pursue alternative trade measures that fall within constitutional boundaries, and geopolitical tensions — including building concerns over Iran — continue to pose risks to emerging-market stability. Still, for now, the court's decision has delivered the clearest positive catalyst for developing economies in months, resetting expectations for growth, trade, and capital flows across the emerging world.

articles.headline: Purpose-Built AI Catches 92% of DeFi Exploits, Dwarfing Generic Models
articles.subheadline: New open-source benchmark reveals domain-specific AI detected vulnerabilities worth $96.8M versus just $7.5M for a standard GPT-5.1 agent
articles.body:
A specialized artificial intelligence security system identified exploitable vulnerabilities in 92 percent of real-world decentralized finance smart contracts that had already been hacked, dramatically outperforming a general-purpose AI coding agent that caught only 34 percent, according to new research published Thursday by AI security firm Cecuro.

The study tested both systems against a benchmark of 90 smart contracts exploited between October 2024 and early 2026, collectively representing $228 million in verified losses. The purpose-built agent flagged flaws tied to $96.8 million in exploit value, while a baseline agent built on OpenAI's GPT-5.1 managed to cover just $7.5 million. Critically, both systems ran on the same underlying frontier model — the performance gap stemmed entirely from domain-specific methodology, structured audit phases, and DeFi-focused security heuristics layered on top by Cecuro's team. Several of the exploited contracts in the dataset had previously passed professional security audits before being drained.

The findings land at a particularly fraught moment for crypto security. Separate research from Anthropic and OpenAI has demonstrated that AI agents can now execute end-to-end exploits on most known vulnerable smart contracts at an average cost of roughly $1.22 per attempt, with offensive exploit capability reportedly doubling every 1.3 months. North Korean hacking operations have already begun integrating AI tools to automate and scale their attacks, widening what researchers describe as a growing asymmetry between offensive and defensive AI capabilities in the crypto ecosystem.

Cecuro has open-sourced its benchmark dataset, evaluation framework, and baseline agent on GitHub, but the firm declined to release its full specialized security agent, citing concerns that the tooling could be repurposed by attackers. The company argues that many DeFi teams continue to rely on general-purpose AI tools or periodic one-off audits — an approach the benchmark data suggests is inadequate for catching the high-value, complex vulnerabilities that sophisticated attackers target.

The research underscores a broader tension in the race between AI-powered offense and defense in decentralized finance. As the cost and technical barrier to launching AI-driven exploits continues to plummet, the results suggest that generic AI models alone are insufficient for meaningful smart contract security — and that the application layer built around a model may matter far more than the model itself.

articles.headline: Canadian Stocks Rally After U.S. Supreme Court Strikes Down Trump Tariffs
articles.subheadline: Canada's benchmark index climbs as the high court's ruling removes a major overhang on North American trade
articles.body:
Canadian equities surged on Thursday after the United States Supreme Court struck down President Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs, removing one of the most significant sources of uncertainty that had weighed on cross-border commerce for months.

Canada's benchmark stock index posted broad-based gains as investors recalibrated their outlook for the country's export-heavy economy. The ruling effectively dismantles a tariff regime that had disrupted supply chains and dampened business confidence across North America, particularly in Canada, where roughly three-quarters of exports are destined for the U.S. market. Sectors with heavy American exposure — including energy, manufacturing, and materials — were among the biggest beneficiaries of the post-ruling rally.

The Supreme Court's decision marks a pivotal moment in the legal battle over Trump's trade agenda, which had drawn challenges from multiple trading partners and domestic industry groups arguing the tariffs exceeded presidential authority. While the full scope of the ruling and its implications for existing trade agreements remain subject to legal interpretation, markets moved swiftly to price in a more favorable environment for Canadian exporters. The Canadian dollar also strengthened against its U.S. counterpart in the wake of the news.

The tariffs had been a persistent drag on Canadian markets since their implementation, prompting retaliatory measures from Ottawa and fueling fears of a broader economic slowdown. Canadian business leaders and policymakers had repeatedly warned that prolonged trade barriers risked undermining the deeply integrated North American economy, where goods and components routinely cross the border multiple times during production.

Analysts cautioned that volatility could persist as the legal and political fallout from the ruling unfolds. The Trump administration could pursue alternative trade measures or seek legislative avenues to reimpose duties, leaving some uncertainty intact. Still, for now, the court's decision has provided a significant tailwind for Canadian equities and a measure of relief to businesses on both sides of the border that had been navigating an unpredictable trade landscape.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Trump's Global Tariffs in 6-3 Ruling
articles.subheadline: Chief Justice Roberts writes majority opinion finding president exceeded his authority; markets rally on the decision
articles.body:
The United States Supreme Court on Thursday declared President Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs unconstitutional, ruling 6-3 that the president overstepped his executive authority in imposing the trade levies. Chief Justice John Roberts authored the majority opinion in what stands as one of the most consequential checks on presidential trade power in decades.

The decision immediately reverberated through financial markets. U.S. equities and Treasury yields jumped on the news, while the dollar weakened — a signal that investors view the removal of tariffs as a net positive for the domestic economy and a potential easing of inflationary pressures that had built up since the duties were first imposed. The tariffs, which targeted imports from countries around the world, had been a cornerstone of Trump's economic agenda and a persistent source of friction with trading partners.

President Trump responded sharply, calling the ruling a "disgrace" — language that underscores the political stakes of the decision and sets the stage for a potential confrontation between the executive branch and the judiciary over the limits of trade authority. The ruling effectively curtails the president's ability to unilaterally impose broad-based tariffs without explicit congressional authorization, a question that legal scholars and trade policy experts have debated since the tariffs were first enacted.

The 6-3 split suggests the court's decision crossed ideological lines, with Roberts — a George W. Bush appointee — leading a coalition that included justices from both conservative and liberal wings of the bench. The ruling carries significant implications not only for current trade policy but for the broader balance of power between Congress and the White House on economic matters. Constitutional experts say the opinion could reshape how future administrations approach tariff authority under statutes like the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and the Trade Expansion Act of 1962.

For businesses and consumers, the practical effect may be substantial. The global tariffs had raised costs across a wide range of imported goods, contributing to elevated prices and supply chain adjustments. Their removal could provide relief to industries from manufacturing to retail, though the timeline for unwinding the tariffs and any potential legislative response from Congress remains unclear. The White House has not yet indicated whether it will seek alternative legal avenues to reimpose the duties.

articles.headline: Trump's Tariff Regime Reshapes Global Trade as Costs Mount
articles.subheadline: A sprawling web of import levies across sectors and countries is altering supply chains and raising prices for businesses and consumers
articles.body:
President Donald Trump's expansive tariff agenda has grown into one of the most aggressive trade policy campaigns in modern American history, imposing levies across a broad swath of industries and trading partners that are rippling through the global economy.

The administration has enacted tariffs targeting steel, aluminum, automobiles, and a wide range of Chinese goods, among other categories, creating a complex and shifting landscape that businesses must navigate in real time. The cumulative effect has pushed the effective U.S. tariff rate to levels not seen in decades, according to trade economists, with some estimates suggesting it now exceeds rates that prevailed before the mid-20th century liberalization of global commerce. China has faced some of the steepest levies, with tariffs on certain goods reaching well above 100 percent after successive rounds of escalation.

The economic consequences are increasingly tangible. Importers face higher costs that many are passing along to consumers, contributing to upward pressure on prices for everything from electronics to household goods. Manufacturers that depend on imported components have been forced to reconfigure supply chains, in some cases shifting sourcing to countries not subject to the highest tariffs — a phenomenon economists call trade diversion. Retaliatory measures from trading partners, particularly China, Canada, and the European Union, have meanwhile squeezed American exporters, especially in agriculture.

The administration has argued the tariffs serve multiple strategic objectives: reducing the U.S. trade deficit, reviving domestic manufacturing, and providing leverage in bilateral negotiations. Some sectors, notably steel production, have seen modest employment gains. But broader economic assessments have been more cautious. Multiple analyses suggest the tariffs function as a tax on American consumers and businesses, with the costs outweighing the targeted benefits. The Federal Reserve and private forecasters have flagged tariff-related uncertainty as a drag on business investment.

As the tariff regime continues to evolve — with pauses, exemptions, and new levies announced at irregular intervals — the lack of predictability has become a challenge in its own right. Companies report difficulty planning capital expenditures when the rules of international commerce can shift with a single presidential announcement. The ultimate economic toll will depend on whether the tariffs prove to be temporary negotiating tools or permanent features of U.S. trade policy, a question that remains unresolved as the administration presses forward on multiple fronts simultaneously.

articles.headline: Trump Announces 10% Global Tariff Hours After Supreme Court Strikes Down Previous Levies
articles.subheadline: President invokes Section 122 authority to reimpose sweeping trade barriers, declares all national security tariffs remain in effect
articles.body:
President Donald Trump moved swiftly on Friday to reimpose broad trade barriers on imports worldwide, announcing a 10% global tariff just hours after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down his administration's earlier tariff regime as unconstitutional.

Speaking at a White House press conference, Trump said the new levy — which would be layered on top of existing duties — would be authorized under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974, a rarely invoked provision that grants the president temporary authority to impose tariffs of up to 15% for 150 days to address large and serious balance-of-payments deficits. The president simultaneously declared that all national security tariffs imposed under Section 232, as well as existing Section 301 tariffs targeting specific countries and industries, remain in full force and effect.

The announcement represents a dramatic legal pivot by the administration, which had relied on broader executive authority to justify its earlier global tariff program before the Supreme Court invalidated that approach. By shifting to Section 122, Trump is effectively daring opponents to mount a fresh legal challenge while maintaining economic pressure on trading partners. Legal experts have noted, however, that Section 122 imposes significant constraints — including a cap on tariff rates and a built-in expiration — that could limit the administration's ability to sustain the policy long-term without congressional action.

The Supreme Court's ruling earlier Friday marked one of the most significant checks on presidential trade authority in decades, finding that the administration had exceeded its statutory power in levying sweeping tariffs without explicit congressional authorization. Markets had initially rallied on the decision, but gains were quickly pared as Trump signaled his intent to find alternative legal pathways to maintain the tariffs. The rapid response underscores the administration's determination to preserve its aggressive trade posture as a cornerstone of economic policy.

The reimposition of a 10% blanket tariff is likely to reignite tensions with major trading partners, including the European Union, China, and Japan, all of which had signaled relief at the court's ruling. Business groups and importers, who had lobbied aggressively against the earlier tariff regime, now face renewed uncertainty over supply chains and input costs. With the Section 122 clock ticking from the moment of imposition, attention will turn quickly to whether Congress moves to codify or block the tariffs — and whether a second round of legal challenges can reach the courts before the duties take full economic effect.

articles.headline: Dubai Opens Secondary Market for Tokenized Real Estate on XRP Ledger
articles.subheadline: The $5 million pilot marks phase two of Dubai's plan to tokenize $16 billion in property by 2033
articles.body:
Dubai's government real estate authority has launched a secondary trading market for blockchain-based property tokens, advancing one of the most ambitious tokenization experiments in the world. The Dubai Land Department (DLD) and infrastructure partner Ctrl Alt announced on Friday that roughly 7.8 million tokens representing fractional ownership in ten Dubai properties — valued at over $5 million — are now eligible for resale on a controlled trading platform.

The tokens, built on Ripple's XRP Ledger and secured through Ripple Custody, are directly backed by title deeds and synced with Dubai's official land registry. A compliance layer using so-called Asset-Referenced Virtual Assets (ARVAs) governs who can trade and under what conditions, ensuring that every transaction is reflected in the emirate's property records. The setup represents a deliberate effort to bridge decentralized blockchain infrastructure with traditional real estate law.

The secondary market launch constitutes the second phase of a pilot that began when the DLD partnered with Ctrl Alt and Prypco to tokenize property deeds on the XRP Ledger. The broader ambition is sweeping: Dubai aims to tokenize 7% of its real estate market — approximately $16 billion worth — by 2033. If successful, the initiative could position the city-state as the global leader in blockchain-based property transactions, where ownership transfers that currently take days or weeks could settle in minutes.

The project arrives at a moment of growing momentum for real-world asset tokenization globally. A Deloitte report published last year projected that $4 trillion in real estate will be tokenized by 2035, implying annual growth of roughly 27%. Yet significant obstacles remain. An EY analysis has noted that uneven regulation across jurisdictions continues to limit adoption, while thin secondary market liquidity — the very problem Dubai's pilot seeks to address — constrains investor interest. In the United States, real estate billionaire Barry Sternlicht has publicly expressed interest in tokenization but cited regulatory barriers as a major impediment.

Dubai's controlled trading environment is designed to test market infrastructure, investor protections, and legal alignment before any broader rollout. While $5 million in tradable property tokens remains a tiny fraction of the emirate's roughly $229 billion real estate market, the pilot's significance lies in what it is proving: that government registries and blockchain settlement can operate in tandem. Whether that model scales to $16 billion will depend on liquidity depth, regulatory durability, and whether investors trust tokens as much as traditional title deeds.

articles.headline: Oil Prices Hold Near Six-Month High Amid Trump's Iran Strike Warning
articles.subheadline: President issues 15-day ultimatum to Tehran over nuclear program as U.S. forces gather in the Middle East
articles.body:
Crude oil prices remained elevated near six-month highs on Thursday after President Donald Trump disclosed he is considering a limited military strike against Iran, injecting fresh geopolitical risk into global energy markets already grappling with tight supply dynamics.

Trump's remarks, in which he warned Tehran it had no more than 15 days to reach an agreement over its nuclear program, came as U.S. military forces were reported gathering in the Middle East. The combination of an explicit ultimatum and visible force posturing sent a clear signal that Washington is prepared to escalate if diplomatic efforts stall. Iran, an OPEC member that produces roughly 3.2 million barrels per day, sits at a critical chokepoint for global oil flows — any disruption to its output or to shipping through the Strait of Hormuz could ripple through markets worldwide.

The threat alone has been sufficient to buoy prices. Oil traders have been pricing in a growing geopolitical risk premium, reflecting the possibility that even a limited strike could trigger retaliatory actions that disrupt regional production or tanker traffic. The Strait of Hormuz, through which approximately 20% of the world's petroleum passes daily, remains the most watched bottleneck in global energy logistics. Market participants are now closely monitoring diplomatic channels for any indication of whether Tehran will engage in negotiations or dig in ahead of the deadline.

The standoff adds another layer of complexity to an oil market already shaped by OPEC+ production management, sanctions enforcement, and shifting demand forecasts. Analysts note that sustained elevated prices could compound inflationary pressures in the United States and Europe at a time when central banks are navigating delicate monetary policy paths. For consumers, a prolonged crisis could translate into higher gasoline and heating costs heading into the spring.

With the 15-day window now ticking, energy markets are likely to remain volatile as traders weigh the probability of a diplomatic resolution against the risk of military action. The coming days will test whether Trump's ultimatum represents a genuine redline or a negotiating tactic designed to force Tehran back to the table.

articles.headline: UK Man Faces 48 Charges for Drugging Wife, Recruiting Men to Assault Her
articles.subheadline: Twelve co-defendants also charged in case spanning decades; trial set for September in Manchester
articles.body:
A man in his sixties from Stockport, Greater Manchester, has been charged with 48 criminal counts for allegedly drugging his wife into unconsciousness and facilitating her sexual assault by multiple men over a period stretching back to the early 2000s.

The husband, who cannot be named for legal reasons, faces charges including conspiracy to rape, sexual assault by penetration, and conspiracy to administer a substance with intent to commit a sexual offence. Twelve other men, ranging in age from 28 to 73, are co-defendants in the case. All 13 appeared at Manchester Minshull Street Crown Court, where seven — including the husband — entered not guilty pleas to all charges. Five defendants were not asked to enter pleas at this stage. One man pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit rape, conspiracy to administer a substance with intent, conspiracy to commit sexual assault by penetration, and one count of committing sexual assault by penetration.

Members of the woman's family were present in the public gallery during the hearing. The allegations describe a prolonged pattern of abuse in which the victim was rendered unconscious before being subjected to sexual violence by her husband and men he allegedly recruited. The case bears striking similarities to the high-profile French trial of Dominique Pelicot, who was convicted in December 2024 of drugging his wife Gisèle and inviting dozens of strangers to rape her over nearly a decade.

A further hearing is scheduled for March, with a full trial set to begin on September 1. The proceedings are expected to last approximately 12 weeks, reflecting the breadth and complexity of the charges. Greater Manchester Police are leading the investigation.

The case underscores ongoing concerns about drug-facilitated sexual violence within intimate relationships — crimes that experts say remain significantly underreported due to victims being unaware of the abuse while it occurs. Legal observers note that the scale of the alleged conspiracy, involving more than a dozen defendants over two decades, makes it one of the most significant cases of its kind to come before UK courts.

articles.headline: Trade-Linked Stocks Surge After Supreme Court Strikes Down Tariffs
articles.subheadline: Retailers, industrials, and automakers rally sharply as high court rules against Trump's sweeping global trade levies
articles.body:
Shares of trade-sensitive companies across the retail, industrial, and automotive sectors jumped sharply on Friday after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down President Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs, removing a major overhang that had weighed on corporate earnings outlooks and supply chain planning for months.

The ruling, which invalidated the broad tariff regime Trump had imposed on imports from countries around the world, sent an immediate jolt through equity markets. Retailers — many of which rely heavily on imported consumer goods — were among the biggest beneficiaries, alongside industrial manufacturers and automakers whose complex global supply chains had been disrupted and made more costly by the levies. The decision effectively unwound one of the most consequential trade policy experiments in modern American history, restoring a degree of certainty to businesses that had struggled to price in the unpredictable tariff landscape.

The Supreme Court's intervention marks a dramatic check on executive trade authority and is likely to reshape the legal and political boundaries of presidential power over commerce. While the specifics of the court's reasoning were not immediately detailed, the market's reaction suggested investors had been pricing in at least some probability that the tariffs would remain in place. The swift rally indicated significant pent-up demand for exposure to trade-dependent sectors that had been under pressure.

For retailers, the ruling could translate into lower input costs and improved margins in coming quarters, particularly for companies that source heavily from Asia. Automakers, which had faced the dual burden of higher component costs and retaliatory measures from trading partners, stand to benefit from both reduced expenses and potentially reopened export markets. Industrial firms with sprawling international operations may see relief on both the cost and revenue sides of their ledgers.

The broader implications for U.S. trade policy remain to be seen. The decision could constrain future administrations' ability to impose unilateral tariffs without congressional approval, fundamentally altering the balance of power over trade. Market participants will be closely watching for any legislative response from Capitol Hill, as well as the administration's next moves in the wake of what amounts to a historic judicial rebuke of its economic agenda.
